skill.name: test-driven-development
skill.description: Red-green-refactor development methodology requiring verified test coverage. Use for feature implementation, bugfixes, refactoring, or any behavior changes where tests must prove correctness.

skill.author: CodingCossack

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with TDD methodology content. No executable code, no network access, no filesystem access, no external command execution. Risk factors: none detected.

content.value_statement: Software breaks when requirements change because tests are missing or inadequate. This skill provides a disciplined red-green-refactor methodology that ensures every behavior change has verified test coverage before code is written.
actual_capabilities: Guide the red-green-refactor cycle with step-by-step verification
Create failing tests that prove correct behavior before implementation
Identify and avoid common testing anti-patterns
Apply TDD to new features, bug fixes, and legacy codebases
Write minimal code that passes tests without over-engineering
Recognize when to refactor safely without breaking tests
limitations: Does not execute tests automatically - requires user to run test commands
Does not generate test code automatically - provides guidance on writing tests
Does not integrate with specific test frameworks - framework-agnostic methodology

use_cases.title: Implement New Features

use_cases.title: Write Effective Unit Tests

use_cases.title: Add Tests to Existing Code
use_cases.description: Use characterization tests to safely refactor code without existing coverage.

prompt_templates.title: Start TDD Session
prompt_templates.scenario: Begin a new feature with TDD
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me apply test-driven development to implement a new feature. Start by listing the test cases I should write first.

prompt_templates.title: Write Failing Test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a failing test for [feature/behavior]. Show me the test structure and what it should verify.

prompt_templates.title: Fix Failing Test
prompt_templates.prompt: My test is failing for the wrong reason [describe issue]. Help me understand why and fix the test setup.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor Safely
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to refactor [component] but maintain all passing tests. What refactoring patterns are safe in TDD?

best_practices: Always run tests and watch them fail before writing production code
Write one minimal test per behavior rather than comprehensive tests upfront
Keep refactoring separate from behavior changes - refactor only when tests are green
anti_patterns: Writing tests after code - this only verifies what you built, not what is required
Testing mock mechanics instead of real behavior and observable outcomes
Keeping code written before tests 'as reference' - delete it and start fresh

faq.question: What programming languages and test frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: This is a framework-agnostic methodology. The principles apply to any language with unit testing support like Jest, pytest, JUnit, or Go's testing package.

faq.question: How long should each red-green-refactor cycle take?
faq.answer: Each cycle should be short, typically 1-5 minutes. If a cycle takes longer, the test or implementation may be too complex and needs simplification.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with existing code that has no tests?
faq.answer: Yes. Use characterization tests to capture current behavior first. Write tests that describe what the code does, then build a safety net for refactoring.

faq.question: Is my test data and code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This is a read-only methodology guide. It does not access, read, or modify any of your files, tests, or code. All testing happens in your local environment.

faq.question: Why is my test passing immediately when it should fail?
faq.answer: A passing test before implementation usually means you are testing existing behavior, not new requirements. Delete the test and write one that describes what should happen but currently does not.

faq.question: How does this compare to test-after development?
faq.answer: TDD forces you to see the test fail first, proving it tests something real. Tests written after code that pass only verify what you built, not what was required. TDD provides evidence that tests catch bugs.
